_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

PINNACLE FOODS - Birds Eye Foods Darien Operations



INTRODUCTION



Birds Eye Foods Darien facility is located at W8880 County Road X, Darien Wisconsin. The facility was built, owned and operated by the Libby, McNeil, Libby Company in 1963. The facility has under gone numerous changes in ownership: Nestle Foods 1976, Larson Company 1980, Dean Foods 1986, Agralink 1998 and Pinnacle Foods 2009. The ammonia refrigeration system was built in 1963 with additions in 1974, 1985, 1989, 2002, 2003, 2008, 2011 and 2012. The system has followed the provisions of the Process Safety Management (PSM) since 1993 and Risk Management Program (RMP) since 1999. 





A. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Birds Eye Foods (BEF) is committed to providing a safe workplace that is operated in an environmentally responsible manner. Birds Eye Foods strives to protect all its valuable resources and assets - both personnel and property. We live and have families in this community. We want to prevent exposure to all our personnel as well as nearby members of our community, existing natural resources, and the surrounding environment. Birds Eye Foods is also committed to complying with all applicable laws and regulations relating to safety in the workplace and the

protection of the environment. Through continual, accurate training and various safety devices and procedures, we work to minimize potential releases.



It is Birds Eye Foods policy that to promote overall public and associate safety by developing, implementing and 

maintaining all required elements of the EPAs RMP provisions and OSHAs PSM standard regarding the storage, handling, and processing of anhydrous ammonia used at this facility. The incorporation of these programs helps to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of highly hazardous materials as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic incidents.



This facility incor

porates a comprehensive management system to oversee the continued development,

Implementation and maintenance of the RMP. The Plant Manager is responsible for the implementation of the RMP. In turn, he has designated the facility Refrigeration Supervisor as the PSM Coordinator having overall authority for and oversight of the Facility PSM program and The Environmental Supervisor has overall authority for, and oversight of, the Facility RMP program. As part of the PSM and RMP, the facility has an Emergency Response Plan and Procedures Manual which provides instructions and responsibilities required of facility personnel in case of the following plant emergencies: employee illness/injury, ammonia release, fire, and severe weather. The management team is committed to safety and the implementation of safe procedures at the facility.





B. FACILITY OVERVIEW AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The facility is located on 600 acres in a rural setting 1.5 miles from the village of Darien. Interstate 43 borders the property on the southwest to northeast boundary. County Road X is on the south with the western border abutting farmland.  The facility consists of one main plant building with over 700,000 square feet under roof. The Darien   facility processes fresh green beans and carrots from July- November and packages frozen vegetables and ready to eat meals year round. We utilize anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration for space cooling of production areas and storage areas for incoming food ingredients and finished product. Ammonia is also used in processing of the ingredients going into the frozen meal products and for freezing of the green beans and carrots. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) considers anhydrous ammonia as hazardous; therefore necessitate certain safety precautions.



As set forth in PSM, BEF Darien uses Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practice (RAGAGEP) as the guideline in our management of the ammonia systems.  The redundancy

built into the system ensures that a release will be minimized and controlled in a short period of time. A nationally recognized, reputable and professional ammonia delivery company is used to recharge the system when needed, which is approximately once a year. Steel piping then carries the ammonia to the refrigeration equipment. Access to the site is restricted to company employees and authorized contractors and visitors. 



Anhydrous ammonia is the only RMP regulated substance (toxic or flammable) above the applicable threshold that is used at our facility. The refrigeration system consists of 4 separate systems with a total of 131,473LBS. The engine rooms are locating within the plant. Each ER is enclosed and has automatic mechanical ventilation and ammonia detection systems designed for the specific room.





C. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



At the Birds Eye Foods (BEF) facility in Darien, Walworth County, Wisconsin, on 7/29/2018, at approximately 4:45am, a fan fell on a piece of evaporation equipment resulting in an ammonia gas vapor release.  It is suspected that the fan motor support bracket failed potentially due to bracket and/or fan/motor design, coupled with corrosion, vibration, and/or metal fatigue.  The release occurred inside the building in the Poly 12 production area.  Employees evacuated outside and eventually to the south employee entrance.  A call was placed to 911 at approximately 4:58 am, while plant staff went to Engine Room 1 to close the liquid ammonia feed valve to the evaporator that was damaged.  The Darien Fire Department arrived onsite and assumed the Incident Command (IC) role.  The Environmental Health and Safety Manager at BEF, Dan Majorowicz, was contacted and arrived onsite at approximately 7:00 am.  Majorowicz called the National Response Center and Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources to alert them of the release.  The Racine Hazmat team arrived and assumed the IC role from the Darien Fire Department.  At 8:30 am, staff co

ntacted Kuhlman Refrigeration for assistance at the plant.  Racine Hazmat team members and a BEF Refrigeration Mechanic went to the roof where the Poly 12 valves were located and turned off four valves.  Monitoring continued and doors were opened as deemed safe to help ventilate the interior areas affected by the release.  All employees that had swiped their entrance cards were accounted for by the Human Resources Manager.  Racine Hazmat team members and a BEF Refrigeration Mechanic went to the Fork Truck repair shop to check ammonia levels throughout the processing floor.  Beginning at approximately 3:30 pm, Racine Hazmat team members, Kuhlman Refrigeration mechanics, and BEF Refrigeration mechanics verified valves were closed and holding.  Racine Hazmat team members entered Poly 12 to check readings around drains from evaporator units.  At approximately 9:30 pm, readings had stabilized in Poly 12.  Racine Hazmat turned IC over to Darien Fire Department. The following morning (7/30/2018) at approximately 2:40 am, the Darien Fire Department turned control of the plant back to BEF management and left the site.



D. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The ammonia refrigeration system design and construction is based upon accepted and proven engineering

design practices for a safe operating refrigeration plant. The system was designed and constructed to meet

the Uniform Building Code, Uniform Mechanical Code, Uniform Fire Code, ANSI / ASHRAE Standard 15 and

the National Electrical Code. Shut-off valves are strategically located throughout the refrigeration system to

allow emergency shut-off, periodic maintenance and repair. Pressure vessels are ASME rated to 250 psig and

fitted with either a single or dual safety relief valve as required by ASME. The facility has an automatic

ammonia detection, notification system, and response system for the engine room and refrigerated spaces.



The facility complies with app

licable Federal, State and Local regulations including the EPA's Accidental

Release Prevention Rule. Personnel are trained about this during our Hazard Communications Training and

through access to our Written Programs.



The facility has reviewed and revised the documents and procedures for compliance with OSHA's PSM and

EPA's Risk Management Program for ammonia use and storage. A management system has been established

to maintain the elements of the PSM and Risk Management Programs. Applicable written elements of the

PSM and the Risk Management Program are readily accessible by employees.





E. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Emergency Planning and Response Plan covers the ammonia refrigeration system in accordance with

Process Safety and Risk Management. Our emergency plan has specific procedures for accidental releases of

anhydrous ammonia as well as other emergencies. If a release of ammonia is detected by the ammonia

detection system or by employees, the procedures within this manual will be followed including notification

of hazardous materials responders (refrigeration technicians) by radio and as required, the involvement of

the incident commander. The manual describes the level of personal protective equipment to be used to

respond to ammonia incidents. Facility responders have received initial and annual refresher training in

accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120. Facility-wide training regarding emergency procedures and evacuation

routes occurs annually.



The facility has an in-house HAZMAT team that initially responds and works in conjunction with the Darien Voluntary Fire Department and the Walworth County Local Emergency Planning Committee on emergency

preparedness. The Darien Fire Departments and Walworth County Sheriff's Department will handle public

notification in coordination with the LEPC. We meet periodically with representatives of each to address any changes in the facility or any new concerns. Birds Eye Foods will work wi

th these agencies as necessary to notify the public about an ammonia release. The manual also contains procedures for emergency alerting and response procedures for on-site personnel, off-site emergency contacts, and adjacent plants. Senior management will handle media relations. 



We strive to minimize off-site consequences through the implementation of emergency response program elements: pre-emergency planning, facility evacuation procedures, emergency response procedures,

emergency medical and first aid procedures, post-emergency guidelines, and training program





F. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



BEF Darien manages all the plant processes through the implementation of Continuous Improvement programs.  We continue to improve the safety of the system by implementing recommendations from various PSM program elements such as Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) reviews, PSM/RMP audits and Mechanical Integrity Assessments (MIA). Our Refrigeration staff is kept current with industry changes through on the job training, offsite seminars and provided with access to the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) and the Industrial Refrigeration Consortium (IRC) publication and training materials.
